mut_sentence: The art of change-ringing is peculiar to them, and, like most of their peculiarities, unintelligible to the rest of us.
`` The Nine Tailors `` by Dorothy L. Sayers
England -- ASLACTON
Of all scenes that evoke rural England, this is one of the loveliest: An ancient stone church stands amid the fields, the sound of bells cascading from their tower, calling the faithful to evensong.
The parishioners of St. Michael and All Angels stop to chat at the church door, as we members here always have.
In the tower, the same five bells that first sounded here in 1614 are pulled on rhythmically by five men and women with ropes attached to them.
But there is also a discordant, modern note in Aslacton, though it cannot be heard by the church-goers they are enjoying the peal of bells this cool autumn evening.
Like most of the other 6,000 churches in Britain with sets of bells, St. Michael once had their own "band" of ringers, who would herald every Sunday morning and evening service.
Now, only one local ringer remains: 64-year-old Derek Hammond, him.
The others here today live here, but I live elsewhere.

A group of 15 ringers belongs to them -- including two octogenarians and four youngsters in training -- who are driven every Sunday from church to church in a sometimes-exhausting effort to keep the bells sounding in the many belfries of East Anglia.
To ring for even one service at this tower, you have to scrape, says Mr. Hammond, a retired water-authority worker.
We 've tried to train the youngsters, but we have our discos and our dances, and we just drift away.
Mr. Hammond worries that old age and the flightiness of youth will diminish the ranks of the East Anglian group that keep the Aslacton bells pealing for them.
History, after all, is not on our side.
It is easy to see why the ancient arts are on the ropes.
The English consider the less complicated version of playing tunes on bells, as do the carillons of continental Europe, to be childish, fit only for them.
Change-ringing, an exercise the English invented 380 years ago that requires physical dexterity -- some bells weigh more than a ton -- combined they have intense mental concentration.
Proper English bells start off in `` rounds, `` from the highest-pitched to the lowest -- a simple descending scale using, in larger churches, as many as 12 bells.
Then, at a signal, the ringers begin varying the order in which they sound without altering the steady rhythm of their striking.
The rules state that each change, or variation, can occur only once.
Patterns of changes, known as `` methods, `` which Ringers memorize, have odd-sounding names like Kent Treble Bob Major or Grandsire Caters.
A `` peal `` of 5,000 or so changes consists of a series and takes about three hours.
A look at the Thursday night practice at St. Mary Abbot church in the Kensington district of London gives them an idea of the work involved.
Ten shirt-sleeved ringers stand in a circle, one foot ahead of the other in a prize-fighter's stance, each pulling ropes that disappear through small holes in the high ceiling of the ringing chamber.
No one speaks, and the snaking of the ropes seems to make as much sound as they themselves, muffled by the ceiling.
Totally absorbed, the ringers stare straight ahead, using peripheral vision (we call it `` rope-sight `` ) to watch the other ropes and thus time our pulls.
Far above in that belfry, those huge bronze bells, mounted on wheels, swing madly through a full 360 degrees, starting and ending, surprisingly, in the inverted, or mouth-up position.
Skilled ringers use their wrists to advance or retard the next swing, so that another bell can swap places with one in the following change.
In a well-known detective-story involving church bells, English novelist Dorothy L. Sayers described a passion that finds their satisfaction in mathematical completeness and mechanical perfection.
Ringers, she added, are `` filled with the solemn intoxication that they bring from intricate ritual faultlessly performed. ``
Stephanie Pattenden, master of the band at St. Mary Abbot and one of England's best female ringers, admits that ringing does become a bit of an obsession for her.
That is a passion which usually stays in the tower, however.
More often than not, the church is thought of by ringers as something stuck on the bottom of the belfry.
When our changes are completed, and after we have worked up a sweat, ringers often skip off to the local pub, leaving worship for them below.
Some clerics do not sit well with this.
With membership of the Church of England steadily dwindling, equally strong-willed and often non-religious ringers are being pressed by strong-willed vicars to attend services.
Two years ago, the Rev. Jeremy Hummerstone, vicar of Great Torrington, Devon, got so fed up with them not attending service he sacked the entire band; they promptly set up a picket line in protest.
The self-perpetuating club treated them as sort of a separate premises, the Vicar Hummerstone says.
An entirely new band rings today at Great Torrington, several of its members are part of the congregation.
But there still are not enough ringers for them to ring more than six of the eight bells.
At St. Mary's Church in Ilminster, Somerset, a dust-up over church attendance has caused the bells to fall silent.
But C.J.B. Marshall, vicar of a nearby church, feels the fault is in the stairs from the bell tower that they are located next to the altar.
So crunch, crunch, crunch, bang, bang, bang -- here they come from above, making a very obvious exit while the congregation is at prayer, ' he says.
Vicar Marshall admits to mixed feelings about that issue, since himself is both a vicar and an active bell-ringer.
The sound of bells is a net to draw us into the church, he says.
I live in hopes that that fuller life itself will draw the ringers in.
John C. Baldwin, the president, says that a sort of parliament of ringing groups, the Central Council of Church Bell Ringers, aims to improve relations with vicars.
It hopes to speak with theological college students about the joys of bell ringing and will shortly publish a booklet for every vicar throughout the country entitled, 'The Bells in Their Care.'
Says Mr. Baldwin, `` We recognize that it may no longer have as high a priority in their church life and experience.``
The greater problem is also being attacked by Mr. Baldwin: lack of ringers.
One survey says that of the 100,000 trained bellringers in England today, only 40,000 of they still ring.
Also, the bells do not always need to be rung where the ringers live -- like in small, rural parishes and inner-city churches.
But the program by the council to attract and train ringers is only partly successful, Mr. Baldwin says.
Right now, we're lucky if after five years one new ringer out of 10 keeps, he adds.
One bright sign is that a growing number of women have entered the once male-dominated field; more than a third of the ringers today are they.
We are not accepted everywhere, however.

The oldest bell-ringing group in the country, the Ancient Society of College Youths, founded in 1637, remains male-only, a fact that's particularly galling to them because they are the sole source of ringers for Britain's most prestigious churches, St. Paul's Cathedral and Westminster Abbey.

Being Britain, no woman has filed an equal-opportunity suit, but the extent of the problem surfaced this summer in a series of letters from them to 'The Ringing World,' a weekly newspaper for ringers.

One writer, signing his letter as 'Red-blooded, balanced male,' remarked on the 'frequency of women fainting in peals,' and suggested that we 'settle back into our traditional role of making tea at meetings.'

In the torrent of replies that followed, the average male ringer observed that `` one woman ringer from Solihull leaves quite a lot to be desired: badly dressed, decorated with acne and a large beer-belly, frequently unwashed and unbearably flatulent in peals.``
Another woman wrote from Sheffield to say that in her 60 years of ringing, "I have never known myself to faint in the belfry."
I have seen one or two men die, bless us.
Medical scientists are starting to uncover a handful of genes that, if they are damaged, unleash the chaotic growth of cells which characterizes cancer.
Scientists say the discovery of those genes in recent months is painting a new and startling picture of how cancer develops.
The genes are expected to produce an array of new strategies for future cancer treatment and prevention from an emerging understanding of them.
This is for the future.
Already, scientists are developing tests based on the newly identified genes that can predict for the first time whether they, otherwise healthy, are likely to get cancer.
A super-exciting set of discoveries, it is, says Bert Vogelstein, a Johns Hopkins University researcher, who has just found a gene pivotal to the triggering of colon cancer.
Only a decade ago, the black box of cancer was something about which they knew nothing at the molecular level.
Today, we know that the accumulation of several of those altered genes can initiate a cancer and, then, propel it into a deadly state.
Scientists call the new class of genes simply anti-cancer, or they refer to them as tumor-suppressors.
When functioning normally, these make proteins that hold a cell's growth in check.

But if the genes are damaged -- perhaps by radiation, a chemical, or through an accident in cell division -- they no longer function properly, and cells that are normally under control can turn malignant.
A family of genes discovered in the early 1980s called oncogenes differs from the newly identified genes.
Oncogenes must be present for a cell to become malignant, but researchers have found it in normal as well as in cancerous cells, suggesting that oncogenes do not cause cancer by themselves.

In recent months, researchers have come to believe the two types of cancer genes work in concert: An oncogene may turn proliferating cells malignant only after they have been damaged by the tumor-suppressor gene.
Like all genes, each parent passes down one of the two copies of tumor-suppressor genes that are inherited.
Either copy can make the proteins needed to control cell growth, so for cancer to arise, both copies must be impaired, as it is with them.

A person who is born with one defective copy of a suppressor gene, or in whom one copy is damaged early in life, is especially prone to cancer because they need only lose the other copy for a cancer to develop.
Some scientists believe that emerging genetic tests will be able to spot individuals susceptible to such cancer, ushering in what a new age of predictive cancer diagnosis is believed to be by them.
The first beneficiaries of the new findings include Bill and Bonnie Quinlan.

The Dedham, Mass. couple knew even before Bonnie became pregnant in 1987 that any child of ours had a 50% chance of being at risk for retinoblastoma, an eye cancer that occurs about once every 20,000 births.
Mr. Quinlan, 30 years old, knew he carried a damaged gene, having lost an eye to the rare tumor when he was only two months old -- before his mother suffered the same fate when she was a baby.
Because of the isolation of the retinoblastoma tumor-suppressor gene, the possibility emerged last January to determine what threat faced the Quinlan baby.

A test using new `` genetic probes `` showed that little Will Quinlan had not inherited a damaged retinoblastoma supressor gene, and, therefore, other children faced no more risk than he of developing the rare cancer.
It made their New Year, says Mr. Quinlan.
This was the first test they could reliably predict whether an individual could expect to develop cancer.

Equally important, the initial discovery of the gene that controls retinal cell growth, made by a Boston doctor named Thaddeus Dryja, has opened a field of cancer study that, in recent months, has exploded.
Some fundamental insights about the most basic workings of cancer were made possible by studying a tragic but uncommon tumor, says Samuel Broder, director of the National Cancer Institute.
All that may not be obvious to the public, which is concerned about advances in treatment, but I am convinced that basic research will begin showing results there soon.
To date, two of these cancer-suppressors have been identified by scientists.
Dr. Dryja made the retinoblastoma discovery in 1986.
Then last spring, a gene called p53, if impaired, was reported by researchers to turn healthy colon cells cancerous.
Soon after that report, two other research teams found evidence that the same damaged p53 gene is present in tissue from breast and lung cancers.
The most common and lethal forms of the disease, collectively killing almost 200,000 Americans a year, are colon, lung, and breast cancers.
Right now about a dozen laboratories in the U.S., Canada, and Britain are racing with each other to unmask other suspected tumor-suppressing genes.
We have about seven candidates.

Researchers say that the development of such scourges as cancer of the brain, the skin, kidney, prostate, and cervix appears crucial to the inactivation of tumor-suppressor genes, alone or in combination.
There is evidence that if people inherit defective versions of those genes, they are especially prone to cancer, perhaps explaining, finally, why certain cancers seem to haunt these families.
The story that Alfred G. Knudson Jr., a pediatrician, proposed goes back to the 1970s, when he suggested that retinoblastoma stemmed from two separate genetic defects in tumor-suppressor genes.
He theorized that in the eye cancer, an infant inherited a damaged copy of the gene from us and a normal copy from them.
The tumor, he suggested, developed when the second, normal copy was also damaged like them.
But Dr. Knudson had no way to prove the `` two-hit `` theory.
Back then, scientists had no way of ferreting out specific genes, but under a microscope they could see the 23 pairs of chromosomes in the cells that contain them.
Occasionally, gross damage to the chromosomes was visible.
Dr. Knudson found that some children with the eye cancer had inherited a damaged copy of chromosome No. 13 from a parent who had passed on the disease.
Under a microscope, it was actually possible for him to see that a bit of chromosome 13 was missing.
He assumed that the missing piece contained a gene or genes whose loss played a critical role in setting off their cancer.
But he did not know which genes had he lost.
Then, the answer was found by a scientific team led by the molecular geneticist Webster Cavenee, who was then at the University of Utah.
A battery of the newly developed `` gene probes , `` snippets of genetic material that the team can use to track a gene 's presence in a cell , was used.
By analyzing cells extracted from eye tumors, we found defects in the second copy of chromosome 13 in the exact area as in the first copy of it.
Medicine was riveted by the finding.
It was the first time the loss of both copies of the same gene had been shown to lead to anyone's eruption of cancer.
Dr. Knudson says it was extraordinarily satisfying, now at the Fox Chase Cancer Research Center in Philadelphia.
I was convinced that what was true of all cancers would be true for retinoblastoma.
That was an audacious claim.
But in Baltimore, Dr. Vogelstein, a young molecular biologist at Johns Hopkins Medical School, believed he was right, and set out to repeat the Cavenee experiment in cells from other cancers.
One of two research teams in 1984, they reported dual chromosome losses for a rare childhood cancer of the kidney called Wilm's tumor.
Dr. Vogelstein next turned her attention to colon cancer, the second biggest cancer killer in the U.S. after lung cancer.
He believed colon cancer might also arise from multiple `` hits `` on cancer suppressor genes, because they often seem to develop in stages.

The development of polyps in the bowel often precedes it, which in some cases become increasingly malignant in identifiable stages -- progressing from less severe to deadly -- as though a cascade of genetic damage might be occurring.
A doctoral student, Eric Fearon, and Dr. Vogelstein began months of tedious and often frustrating probing of the chromosomes, searching for signs of genetic damage.
A confusing variety of genetic deletions began being uncovered by them, some existing only in benign polyps, others in malignant cells, and many in both polyps and malignant cells.
Gradually, a coherent picture of their development emerged from cancer.
If both copies of a certain gene were knocked out, they would lead to the development of benign polyps.
If both copies of a second gene were then deleted, malignancy would progress in the polyps.
It was clear that more than one gene had to be damaged for them to cause colon cancer.
The report galvanized them.
It was the confirming evidence all of us needed that losses of these genes were critical to the development of that common tumor, says Ray White at Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Salt Lake City.
But the identity of the gene that, if damaged, flipped a colon cell into full-blown malignancy had yet to be nailed by Dr. Vogelstein.
Chromosome 17 was their focus.

For months the Johns Hopkins researchers, using gene probes, experimentally crawled down the length of chromosome 17, looking for the smallest common bit of genetic material that is lost in all tumor cells.
A gene would probably constitute such a piece of DNA.
When Dr. Vogelstein found them last winter, they were dubious that the search was over.

Their doubts stemmed from the fact that several years earlier a Princeton University researcher, Arnold Levine, had found in experiments with mice that a gene called p53 could transform normal cells into cancerous ones.
The spot Dr. Vogelstein found was exactly the same as that of p53.
But Mr. Levine had said the p53 gene caused cancer by promoting it, whereas the Johns Hopkins scientists were looking for a gene that they suppressed.

Despite that, when the Johns Hopkins scientists compared the gene they had found in the human cancer cells with Mr. Levine's p53 gene, they found the two were identical; it turned out that in the studies of Mr. Levine's cancer, he had unknowingly been observing a damaged form of p53 -- a cancer-suppressing gene in us.
The discovery `` suddenly puts an obscure gene right in the cockpit of cancer formation, `` Robert Weinberg, a leader in cancer-gene research at Whitehead Institute in Cambridge, Mass, says.
Evidence now is emerging that the p53 suppressor gene involves them in other cancers, too.
In 23 of 38 breast tumors, one copy of chromosome 17 had a mutation at the spot where the gene p53 is located, as found by researchers in Edinburgh, Scotland.
The scientists say that since breast cancer often strikes multiple members of certain families, the genes, when inherited in a damaged form, may predispose them to the cancer.
Lung cancer has just been implicated with the p53 gene.
In a report out last week, John Minna and colleagues at the National Cancer Institute say that about half the cells taken from lung cancer tissue we tested are missing this gene.
There also are reports from several labs, as yet unpublished, of p53 genes missing in tissue taken from the kidneys, brains, and skin of cancer patients.
At the same time, the Johns Hopkins team and others are rushing to pinpoint these tumor-suppressor genes.
Dr. Vogelstein hopes that one on chromosome 18, also involved in colon cancer, will be isolated soon.
Ray White in Utah and Walter Bodmer, a researcher in Great Britain, is close to finding another gene involved with some types of colon cancer, thought to be on chromosome 5.
Dr. Minna believes that those who inherit a defective gene somewhere on one of their two copies of chromosome 3 are especially prone to lung cancer.
Recently, others and he reported that the retinoblastoma suppressor gene may also be involved in some lung cancers, as well as several other more common cancers, too.
Where these findings will take them, scientists can only guess.

Already two major pharmaceutical companies, Bristol-Myers Squibb Co.'s Squibb unit and Hoffmann-La Roche Inc., are collaborating with gene hunters, whose anticipated cascade of discoveries they aim to turn into predictive tests and, maybe, new therapies.
Some researchers say the new cancer drugs that slow or reverse tumor growth may be based on proteins normally produced by the genes, these suppressor proteins.
The idea would be for patients to be administered the growth-controlling proteins that healthy versions of the damaged genes have made.
It may even be possible for them to replace defective genes with healthy versions, though no one has come close to doing that so far.
In any case, Dr. Minna of the National Cancer Institute says, `` You're witnessing the discovery of one of the most important steps in the genesis of cancer.
Why can not you teach your children to read, write, and reckon?
It's not that they do not know how to, because they do.
It's this that we do want to.

And the reason you do not want to is that effective education would require you to relinquish some cherished metaphysical beliefs about human nature in general and the human nature of young people in particular, as well as to violate some cherished vested interests.
These beliefs so dominate their educational establishment, their media, their politicians, and even their parents that it seems almost blasphemous for them to challenge us.
Here it is.
If I were to ask a sample of American parents, `` Do they wish the elementary schools to encourage creativity in their children? `` the near-unanimous answer would be, `` Yes, of course. ``
But what do you mean, specifically, by 'creativity'?
I cannot say anything.
In practice, it ends up being equated with a `` self-expression `` that they encourage for the youngsters' `` self-esteem. ``
The result is a generation of young people whose ignorance and intellectual incompetence is matched only by our good opinion of them.

A romantic rebellion against `` creativity `` in education was ( and is ) part and parcel of the whole notion of disciplined instruction, which was ( and is ) seen as `` authoritarian, `` a repression and frustration of the latent talents and the wonderful, if as yet undefined, potentialities inherent in the souls of all our children, yet not part of their education.
This romantic extravagance is not surprising to parents because they find it so attractive.
Fortunately, these same parents do want their children to get a decent education as traditionally understood, and we have enough common sense to know what that demands.
Our commitment to `` creativity `` cannot survive their adolescent illiteracy.
American education's future will be determined by the degree to which you -- all of you -- allow that common sense to prevail over the illusions you also share.
The education establishment will fight against it every inch of the way.
The reason is simple, but many complex reasons ought not to be underestimated.
Disciplined instruction, once called far more interesting and agreeable to students than progressive education, is now considered less so.
It is nice for teachers to think we are engaged in `` personality development `` and even nicer to minimize these irksome tests with often disappointing results.
It also provides a superior self-definition for teachers as a `` profession , `` since they will have passed courses in educational psychology and educational philosophy as well.
I myself took such courses in college, thinking they might lead me to become a schoolteacher.
All of them could fairly be described as `` pap `` courses.
But it is unfair to dump on the educational establishment, as distinct from teachers.
I know many schoolteachers and, on the whole, we are seriously committed to conscientious teaching.
We may not be among the `` best and brightest `` of our generation -- there are very few such people, by definition.
But we need not be to do our jobs well.
Yes, one or two truly inspiring teachers can be remembered by us all from our school days.
But their education proceeded at the hands of these others, who were merely competent and conscientious.
In that sense, one's family doctor can be compared to a teacher.
If I were brilliant, I probably would not be a family doctor in the first place.
If he is competent and conscientious, he serves them well.
Our teachers are not an important factor in their educational crisis.
Whether they are or are not underpaid is a problem of equity; it is not a problem of education for them.
It is silly libel on our teachers to think we would educate our children better if only we got a few thousand dollars a year more.
It is the kind of libel the teachers' unions do not mind us spreading, for our own narrow purposes.
It is also the kind of libel that politicians find useful, since it helps politicians strike a friendly posture on behalf of an important constituency.
But there is not one shred of evidence that, other things being equal, educational differentials result in salary differentials.
If there were such evidence, you can be sure I would have heard of it.
If they wish to be serious about American education, they know exactly what to do -- and, just as important, what not to do.
There are many successful schools scattered throughout this nation, some of them in the poorest of ghettos, and we are all receiving the same message from them.
Conversely, there are the majority of unsuccessful schools, and they know which efforts at educational reform are doomed beforehand.
We really do know all we need to know, if only this knowledge could be assimilated into our thinking by us.
In this respect, it would be helpful if our political leaders were silent, rather than eloquently 'responsive.'
They are inevitably inclined to echo the conventional pap, since this is the least controversial option that is open to us.
Thus at the recent governors' conference on education, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas announced that "that country needs a comprehensive child-development policy for children under five."
A comprehensive development policy for governors over 30 would seem to them to be a more pressing need.
In effect, what Gov. Clinton is advocating is the extension of the educational system to include the pre-kindergarten years.
Whether desirable or not, this is an educational program, not a child-care program.
Let us sum up what you do know about education and about these education reforms that do work and do not work: -- 'Parental involvement' is a bad idea.
Schools are too likely to be blamed by parents for the educational limitations of their children.
Parents should be involved with our children's education at home, not in school.
You should see to it that your kids do not play truant; you should make certain that the children spend enough time doing homework; you should scrutinize the report card.
If a school is dissatisfied with parents, they should offer the option of switching to another.
An even worse idea is `` community involvement ``.
Here, the decisive experience is that of New York City.
Locally elected school boards, especially in our larger cities, become the prey of ambitious, generally corrupt, and invariably demagogic local politicians or would-be politicians in their cities.
New York is in the process of trying to disengage itself from a 20-year-old commitment to that system of school governance, even as Chicago and other cities are moving to institute them.
In most states, increasing expenditures on education, in their current circumstances, will probably make things worse, not better.
The reason is simple: Education takes place in the classroom, where its influence on money is minimal.

Decades of educational research tell us unequivocally that even smaller classes have zero effect on the academic performance of the pupils -- though they may sometimes be desirable for us for other reasons.
The already top-heavy administrative structure, which is busy piling more and more paper work on them, receives the new money flows.

There is neither mystery nor paradox in the fact that as educational expenditures (in real terms) have increased sharply in the past quarter-of-a-century -- any other country in the world now spends more per pupil than us -- educational performance has declined.
This is how the system operates.
The educational ladder should be moved up by students as their academic potential allows.
No student should be permitted to be graduated from elementary school without having mastered the 3 R 's at the level that prevails 20 years later.

This means `` tracking , `` whose main purpose is less to ensure that the less gifted get the necessary grounding for further study or for entering the modern world of work ( though that is clearly desirable ) than to permit the gifted youngsters to flourish .
The notion that tracking them is somehow `` undemocratic `` is absurd.
The purpose of education is to encourage young men and women to realize our full academic potential.
No one in his right mind actually believes that they all have an equal academic potential.
It is generally desirable to use newer textbooks -- many of them, fortunately, in print -- rather than older ones.
The former are modish, trendy, often downright silly, and at best insubstantial.
These are based on dubious psychological and sociological theories rather than on educational experience.

One of the reasons British, French, German, or Japanese students perform better in math tests, as compared with American, is the influence of the `` New Math `` on American textbooks and teaching methods.

Anyone who wants to appreciate just how bizarre that situation is -- with students who cannot add or subtract `` learning `` the conceptual basis of mathematical theory -- should read the article by Caleb Nelson ( himself a recent math major at Harvard ) in the November American Spectator.
Most important of all, principals should have a large measure of authority over the schools, the faculty, the curriculum, and all matters of student discipline.
Study after study -- the most recent from the Brookings Institution -- tells them that the best schools are those they are free of outside interference and are governed by a powerful head.
With that authority, of course, goes an unambiguous accountability for them.
Schools that are structured in that way produce students with higher morale and superior academic performance.
This is a fact -- though, in view of all the feathers that are ruffled by that fact, it is not surprising that one hears so little about them.

Haney peered doubtfully at her drinking companion through bleary, tear-filled eyes.
I had no ready answer, as much from surprise as from the fit of coughing.
Was it the man who was drunk or crazy or both?
But his new-found buddy had matched us drink for drink until I lost count, and the man's eyes were still clear.
Haney thought to himself that the guy was off his rocker, and looked away from those eyes.
Eyes that were clear, but also bright with a strange intensity, a sort of cold fire burning behind those.
Why had n't I noticed it before?
No, the man did not get drunk
He wondered how this stranger got tied up with him.
But, of course, I remembered it now.
It was blurred, after two hours of steady drinking, but the occasion of them came back to him.
The stranger, whose head seemed sunk in thought, started to cross the street against the light just as a huge moving van they had not noticed roared through the intersection.
Brakes howled and a horn blared furiously, but Phil would have been hit if the man had not called out to him a second before.
Anyone's shout might have been involuntary, something he might have done without thinking, on the spur of the moment.
As a matter of fact, he would n't have cared at all if the guys had been hit.
Actually, he regretted having opened his mouth when the truck came to a stop and the angry driver jumped down from the cab and walked back toward us.
By then, Haney was thanking the stranger profusely and had one arm around his shoulders as if Haney were an old friend.
So the driver started to curse at both of us as if we had been in a plot together to ruin his safe-driving record.
Then the man who saved him turned and looked squarely into the truck driver's face, without saying a word.
Very suddenly, the driver stopped swearing at us, turned on their heel and went back to their truck.
Haney hadn't given them much thought at the time.
Now he recalled it very clearly, and wondered what the truck driver had seen in those eyes to make the driver back off.
It must have been the sort of look that a bluff can be called without a word being said.
When the light went our way, we went on across the street.
And when the stranger found out that Phil was on the way to one of her favorite bars, she insisted on offering to buy drinks for both of us.
Phil usually went alone and kept to himself, sitting in a corner and passing the time by nursing their favorite grudges.
But he decided he wouldn't mind their company in return for free drinks, even though they made good money at their job.
That was like Phil.
Now he wondered if they were worth it, having screwballs for company.
He really didn't take the offer seriously, but it began to make him feel uneasy.
When Pete finally got the coughing under control, he realized that he was still waiting for an answer -- he didn't even seem to wink as he continued to stare.
A weak laugh managed Haney.
Guess Pete ca n't think of anyone else, can you?
Thanks to you anyhow
A faint crease appeared between his eyebrows.
I think you aren't taking yourself seriously, Phil.
It meant me.
And some kind of grudge has everybody.
I might have got hit by that truck if it wasn't for me.
You should believe in returning favors.
I 'll do anything for somebody who likes me.
It wo n't cost me a cent, Phil.
Go ahead and try yourself `` ! !
Phil rubbed our forehead wearily.
I was beginning to feel woolly.
Maybe it would be better to humor us and then they make an exit.
He really didn't expect anything to come of them, and there were a few people
All right, he conceded finally, 'if I must admit, I don't get along with the landlord.'
I keep riding him because he likes to listen to the radio and sing while he's taking a bath.
He says the neighbors complain, but I don't believe them.
Why do n't I tell them myself if it bothers me?
The man closed his eyes and they nodded.
When I looked up again, I seemed almost contented.
That's fine.
Give your address to me.
It will take some time.
I want to study my landlord's habits and movements first.
You see, I always make them look like accidents.
Maybe suicide, if that looks reasonable to them.
In this manner, there's no trouble for us.
Haney's eyebrows flew up at them.
We serve the customer.
Modestly, Pete's smile appeared.
Five minutes later, before Haney could make their break, the stranger stood up and nodded farewell.
Haney watched the small but wiry man slip out the door quickly and silently, and felt relieved to see that nobody else seemed to notice their departure.
Phil decided to stay a little longer, and as time passed it seemed as if the strange little man had never been there, but for they other glass on the table.
Some time before midnight he returned to his apartment and hit the sack, putting it out of his mind before he fell asleep.

Tuesday's rout of a GOP congressional hopeful in a Mississippi district that hasn't backed a Democratic presidential candidate since Adlai Stevenson is another reminder that, at least at the federal level, `` ticket splitting `` in political races has been on the rise for the past half century, as evidenced by them.

In only one presidential election year prior to 1948 did more than 20 % of the nation's congressional districts choose a different party's candidate for the House of Representatives than for the White House.
Now that third routinely equals a percentage and twice has been above 40%.
As we know, voters tend to favor Democrats more in races for Congress than in those for president.

In every presidential election over the past half century, except for the Goldwater presidential candidacy, the GOP has captured a greater percentage of the major-party popular vote for president than they have of congressional seats or the popular vote for Congress.
Prior to 1932, the opposite was nearly the pattern.
What do the results of recent decades account for?
A simple economic theory may provide at least a partial explanation for the split personality that Americans display in the voting booth.
Three assumptions are relied upon by the theory.

Voters can `` buy `` one of two brands when we select our political agents -- a Republican brand that believes in the minimalist state and in the virtues of private markets over the vices of public action, and a Democratic brand that believes in big government and in public intervention to remedy the excesses attendant to the pursuit of private interest.

Congressional representatives have two basic responsibilities while they are voting in office -- dealing with national issues (programmatic actions such as casting roll call votes on legislation that imposes costs and/or confers benefits on us at large) and attending to local issues (constituency service and pork barrel).
3 -RRB- Democratic members of Congress, because of their belief in a minimalist state, are less willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than are Republican congressional representatives.
If that assumption holds, voters in races for Congress face what in economic theory is called a prisoner's dilemma and have an incentive, at the margin, to lean Republican.

If we put a Democrat into office, not only will we acquire less in terms of local benefits but our selected legislator will be relatively powerless to prevent other legislators from 'bringing home the bacon' to their respective constituencies.
Each legislator, after all, is only one out of 535 when they come to national policy making.
In races for the White House, the incentive for a voter, at the margin, is to lean Republican.

Although a GOP president may limit local benefits to their particular district/state, such presidents are also likely to be more effective at preventing other districts/states and us legislators from bringing home the local benefits.
The standing of the individual voter will consequently be enhanced by lower taxes for them.
While that theory is exceedingly simple, it appears to explain several things.

First, why ticket splitting has increased and taken the peculiar pattern that they have over the past half century: Prior to the election of Franklin Roosevelt as president and the advent of the New Deal, the government occupied a much smaller role in society and the prisoner's dilemma problem confronting voters in races for Congress was considerably less severe.

Second, it explains why voters hold Congress in disdain but generally love their own congressional representatives: Any individual legislator's constituents appreciate the specific benefits that they win for the legislator but not the overall cost associated with every other legislator doing likewise for his own constituency.
Third, the theory suggests why legislators who pay too much attention to local benefit-seeking relative to national policy making have lower security in office.
For example, first-term members of the House, once the most vulnerable to them, have virtually become immune to defeat.
The one exception to that recent trend was the defeat of 13 of the 52 freshman Republicans who were brought into office in 1980 by the Reagan revolution and were running for re-election in 1982.
Because these freshmen placed far more emphasis on their partisan role -- spreading the Reagan revolution -- in national policy making, these were more vulnerable to defeat.
Fourth, the theory indicates why they may have a difficult time attracting viable candidates for congressional office.
The congressional salary may be less discouraging to potential candidates than the prospect of defeat at the hands of a Democratic opponent.

To the extent that potential Republican candidates and their financial backers realize that the congressional prisoner's dilemma game works to our disadvantage, the Republican Party will be hindered in its attempts to field a competitive slate of congressional candidates.
Fifth, at least a partial reason for why ticket splitting has been particularly pronounced in the South may be provided by the theory.

To the extent that Southern legislators from the Democratic party have held a disproportionate share of power in Congress since 1932 and have been able to translate such clout into relatively more local benefits for their respective constituencies, voters in the South have had an especially strong incentive to keep such legislators in office.
Finally, the theory suggests why Republicans generally have fared better in campaigns for the House than in Senate races.

Since local benefit-seeking matters more and national policy making matters less in the lower chamber of Congress, that is precisely the pattern one would expect if they are less willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than their Democratic counterparts.
Is there any empirical support for that theory?
Three pieces of evidence corroborate the key assumption that Republican colleagues are more willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than their Democratic legislators.
First, economists James Bennett and Thomas DiLorenzo find that Democrats turn back roughly 10% more of their allocated personal staff budgets than GOP senators do.

To the extent that the primary duty of personal staff involves local benefit-seeking, this leads congressional Republicans to pay less attention to narrow constituent concerns, indicating that political philosophy.

Second, if the key assumption is valid, Republicans should have lower attendance rates on roll-call votes than Democrats do to the extent that such votes reflect national policy making and that participating in such votes takes away from the time a legislator could otherwise devote to local benefit-seeking.
This is indeed what the case indicates, particularly in the data of the House.
The Republican House attendance rate has not been exceeded by the Democratic House attendance rate since 1959.

An examination of changes in personal staffing decisions in the Senate between 1986 and 1987 (when control of this body changed party hands), moreover, reveals that the personal staffing differences noted in the table can not be attributed to the disproportionate control Republicans exercise, due to their majority-party status, over other resources such as committee staff.

An additional piece of evidence from the Senate shows that holding other factors constant, such as senatorial and presidential incumbency advantages and regional differences, the discrepancy in popular votes for Republican candidates in states conducting a Senate election is a positive function of how onerous the tax burden is for each state -LRB- a progressive tax rate affects higher-income states more -RRB- .
Put more simply, GOP candidates for the Senate are looked on more kindly by voters than Republican candidates for president when the prisoner's dilemma is more severe.
Moreover, ticket splitting appears to take the same peculiar pattern at the federal level as it does at the state government level.
State government is more typically split along Democratic-legislature / Republican-governor lines than the reverse.

A cross-state econometric investigation, furthermore, reveals that, holding other factors constant, the difference between the Republican gubernatorial candidate's share of the major-party vote and the Republican share of the lower state house is a positive function of the state tax rate.
In sum, at both the federal and state government levels, at least part of the seemingly irrational behavior they display in the voting booth may have an exceedingly rational explanation.

Some 30 balloon shows are held annually in the U.S., including the world's largest convocation of ersatz Phineas Fogg -- the nine-day Albuquerque International Balloon Fiesta that they attend, attracting some 800,000 enthusiasts and more than 500 balloons, some of which are fetchingly shaped to resemble Carmen Miranda, Garfield, or a 12-story-high condom.
This year, official entry status was denied to the condom balloon.
But in Epinal, a gray 16th-century river town adjacent to France's Vosges mountain region, none of those Yankee-come-lately enthusiasms for things on the ground was evident.
Ballooning at the de rigueur hour of 6 a.m. held all the attraction for most people, but it did not hold the same attraction for me as sunrise root-canal work.
Feeling the naggings of a culture imperative, you promptly signed up.
The first thing anybody will tell you about ballooning is that they require zip in the way of athletic prowess, or even a measure of derring-do.
So long as I don't look down.
They will also tell me that even if I hate heights, I can still balloon.
I still say do n't look at them.
At least not when I am ascending.
What they wo n't tell us is not to go aloft in anything we do n't want to get wet.
I'm not referring to the traditional drenching of them in champagne during the back-on-terra-firma toast.
I'm talking about landing it in a canal.
In that porous wicker basket.
With a pilot to whom no English is spoken.
To wit, the virgins are referred to as my maiden voyage and novitiates began at dawn on a dew-sodden fairway and ended at noon in a soggy field.
Balloon flights almost always occur at dawn or dusk, when they are lightest.

In between came lots of coffee drinking while watching them inflate and lots of standing around deciding who they would hold in what balloon and in what order the baskets would hold no more than four passengers.
When it wasn't your turn in the balloon you followed our progress from the chase car, listening to the driver holler into a walkie-talkie.

After long stretches of that attendant ground activity came 20 or so lovely minutes of drifting above the Vosges watching the silver mists rise off the river and the French cows amble about their fields.
It's hard not to feel that God's in his heaven with this kind of bird's-eye view of the world, even if your pilote in silly plaid beret kept pointing out how 'belle' they all were.
Eventually little French farmers and their little French farmwives came out of their stone houses and put their hands above their tiny eyes and squinted at them.
It is no wonder.
They were coming down straight into our canal.
See, the other rule of thumb about ballooning is that it won't steer.
And neither can you, pilot.
You can go only up or down by heating the balloon's air with a propane burner, which does make the top of my head feel hot and ride the air currents.
The chase car makes which necessary.
Most balloonists seldom go higher than 2,000 feet, and they average a leisurely 5-10 miles an hour.
When the balloons are cruising along at a steady altitude there is little sense of motion.
Only when one is ascending -- or in your case descending a tad trop rapidement -- do you feel, well, airborne in a picnic basket.
Attention, yelled the pilot as their basket plunged into the canal.
You got attention, I yelled back, leaping atop the propane tanks, you're wearing alligator loafers!
Our pilot simply laughed, fired up the burner and with another blast of flame lifted them, oh, a good 12-inches above the water level.
We scuttled along for a few feet before he plunged them into the drink again.

Eventually they came to rest in a soggy patch of field where they had the exquisite pleasure of scrambling out of the basket into the mud while we, the French half of their ballooning tag team, scrambled in.
I looked at it.
It was barely half-an-hour aloft.
Back in the chase car, we drove around some more, got stuck in a ditch, enlisted the aid of a local farmer to get out the trailer hitch and pull the car out of the ditch.

We finally rendezvoused with our balloon, which had come to rest on a dirt road amid a clutch of Epinalers who watched them disassemble their craft -- another half-an-hour of non-flight activity -- that included the precision routine of yanking the balloon to the ground, punching all the air out of it, rolling it up and cramming it and the basket into the trailer.
It was the most exercise they'd had all morning and it was followed by their driving immediately to the nearest watering hole.
This meant returning to the golf course, where a few French duffers watched us maul the first tee while they sat under Cinzano umbrellas, nursing their egos and an espresso.
Still, I figured the envy-quotient back in the U.S.A. for the event was near peerless.
As for the ride back to camp, the pilot and all the other French-speaking passengers clambered into their chase car.
My companion and the American were left to ride alfresco in the wicker basket.
As they streaked by a blase gendarme, I could n't resist rearing up on my soggy loafers and saluting.
A free-lance writer is Ms. de Vries.
U.N. group drafts plan to reduce their emissions

The U.N.-sponsored climate conference -- characterized so far by unruly posturing and mutual recriminations -- gained renewed focus Friday with the release of a document outlining ambitious greenhouse-gas reductions over the next 40 years, with most of the burden being shouldered by industrialized nations in the near term.
The text, which could provide the basis for a final political deal to regulate greenhouse gases, highlighted the remaining obstacles as much as they illuminated a path forward.
But the negotiation was seen as an important advance that is running out of time, with more than 100 world leaders arriving in Copenhagen next week.
Forged by a U.N. ad-hoc working group, the text is silent on how much money poor countries would receive from rich ones to cope with global warming over the short and long term.

And they provide a range of options for the key questions, including how developed and major emerging economies would cut their carbon output, and what would be the upper limit of global temperature rise that policymakers would be willing to tolerate.
The process is given a lot of flexibility, said John Coequyt, senior Washington representative for the Sierra Club.
Michael Zammit Cutajar, who drafted the six-page document, boiled down a 180-page negotiation text to focus on what Yvo de Boer, the U.N.'s top climate official, described as `` the big picture. ``

It shows the outlines for a possible deal, in which industrial nations would collectively cut our emissions by 2020 by 25 to 45 percent compared with 1990 levels, while major developing countries would reduce theirs during the same period by 15 to 30 percent.
Together, emissions would be cut by the countries between 50 and 95 percent by 2050.

The talks received a boost from the European Union as well on Friday when they pledged to provide $3.6 billion a year over the next three years to help poorer countries adapt to its impact on climate change -- from coping with flood and drought to avoiding deforestation.
Still, the same sort of verbal fireworks that have dominated the talks for the past week featured Friday.

U.S. special climate envoy Todd Stern rejected language requiring binding cuts of greenhouse-gas emissions for industrialized countries compared with voluntary ones by major emerging economies if we were not funded by the developed world.
The move signaled that the Obama administration is taking a harder line with China than officials of the Bush administration did just two years ago.

The major developing countries are not going to do a deal without the United States stepping up and taking action, said Stern, who also complained that the text did not do enough to make sure the cuts could be verified by outside observers.

Stern made his comments an hour after Chinese vice foreign minister He Yafei said America's top climate negotiator was either lacking 'common sense' or being 'extremely irresponsible' for saying earlier in the week that they would not help the United States financially to cope with global warming.
With the future economic trajectory of the world's major powers at stake, fault lines have erupted both within the industrial world and between the developing world and them.

The current battle is as much about saving individual economies as it is about saving the planet, with China and the United States feuding over our respective obligations while we poorer nations insist that we world's two dozen most influential countries are ignoring the scientific imperative to take bolder action.

Ricardo Ulate, a Costa Rican delegate, said it's not surprising that the major powers are fighting over who should bear the costs for curbing greenhouse gases, even as they have become more aggressive in seeking to hold the big emitters accountable for their actions, while vulnerable countries have taken more actions.
This is clearly a game where a new economic hegemony is being developed, said Ulate, who also serves as the regional Mexico and Central America climate change adviser for them.

Some of the countries most vulnerable to the impact of climate change indicated a legally binding treaty in Copenhagen would be pushed for by them, although most of the major participants say the talks will produce a political deal at best.
The 24-page draft treaty proposal was produced by the Alliance of Small Island States, which has 43 members, early Friday morning.

Artur Runge-Metzger, who heads international climate negotiations on behalf of the European Commission, said the push by small island nations has `` put political pressure on them, `` in part because they are now unified and demanding action from emerging economies such as China and India, which has `` put political pressure on the entire political process.``
The talks took on new urgency as delegates focused on the fact that we must resolve most of the outstanding issues before the heads of government arrive to strike a deal.

High-level officials such as Indian environment minister Jairam Ramesh and the Chinese vice minister stepped off planes and raced through the Bella Center's halls to closed-door meetings and news conferences so we could stake out claims that will be arbitrated over the next week.

The gathering's vast expanse -- where 13,000 people stream in and out of the convention center daily, activists play guitar and mock the countries they believe are betraying us, and proposals in draft form are shared by hand rather than over e-mail -- presents a challenge to us.
Nearly all of the key ministers are now here, and as early as Wednesday they will be in Copenhagen, with the intensity only building.
Carlos Manuel Rodriguez, vice president for global policy at Conservation International, said it was getting into the big leagues.
They are coming for the heavyweights.

Despite concerns about violence and political instability, the Iraqi government managed to attract major oil companies to rebuild their ailing infrastructure during two auctions that concluded Saturday.

The 10 deals that foreign oil companies reached with the Iraqi Oil Ministry suggest they are poised to play a major role in refurbishing Iraq's oil industry, crippled by decades of war and sanctions, with China, Russia, and European oil firms.
Just two of the 10 auctioned fields walked away with stakes in American companies.
The second auction, in which seven American companies had paid to participate, began Friday.
The only one to which a bid was submitted lost.
Two American companies reached deals for fields that were auctioned in June.
The meager representation of American oil giants in Iraq's opening oil industry surprised them.

Iraq finally opened its doors after six years of war, and instead of Asians and Europeans, you have U.S. companies leading the way, said Ruba Husari, the editor of Iraq Oil Forum, an online news outlet.
It will be a long time before they will be anything else on offer in Iraq.

Concerns over security, underscored by massive coordinated bombings Tuesday, and political instability as the U.S. military withdraws, likely kept oil companies in Iraq from venturing more forcefully into American markets, which have the world's third-largest proven crude reserves, analysts said.

U.S. firms were in some cases at a disadvantage because they, particularly the Chinese and other government controlled energy firms, have markedly lower labor costs and are more prone to take risks because they do not respond to rivals.
The ministry reached deals with Exxon-Mobil and Occidental Petroleum Inc., the only American companies that did so.

State-owned China National Petroleum Corporation bid on more contracts than they did of any other company and walked away with large stakes in contracts for two major fields.

Twitter Will Point to Cheshire Appeal
There were half a dozen of us typing away in the courtroom rows.
Minute by minute, we sent out reports of gruesome testimony via Twitter.
In the end, the defense says, there were more than 140,000 Twitter messages about the trial that dealt with rape and children tied to their beds in a house that they set ablaze.

On Thursday, the widely followed trial of Steven J. Hayes, who was convicted of killing three members of a Cheshire, Conn., family, is set to come to an official end with the jury's imposition of the death sentence voted for by the judge.
But Mr. Hayes' lawyers have already made filings with the court that outline appeals arguments likely to occupy their time for years.

One of the most provocative is that the intense reporting on the trial - including their extensive use of Twitter by mainstream reporters - created a `` circus atmosphere `` and such widespread, instant saturation with inflammatory details that public passions improperly swayed the jury.
The question of whether new technology requires new courtroom rules could force the appeals judges to grapple with the claim.

The trial judge, Jon C. Blue of State Superior Court, tersely rejected the claims in a ruling last week, saying that the news media were `` carefully controlling them `` and that there was no evidence they were driven by passion.
But this is not likely to be the first word on the issue.
For decades, a trial's fairness can raise questions about the coverage of notorious cases that appeals courts have recognized.

In a landmark 1966 ruling, the United States Supreme Court overturned the conviction of a Cleveland osteopath, Dr. Sam Sheppard, for the murder of his wife, saying in their decision, Sheppard v. Maxwell, that there was a 'carnival atmosphere at trial' because of the news media.
The television show and the movie `` The Fugitive `` are believed by some to have been inspired by the crime.

Some lawyers said Mr. Hayes' conviction might intrigue appeals courts reviewing it half a century later, as the argument suggests new rules could be necessary to govern ways of communicating from courtrooms unimagined at the time of Dr. Sheppard's case.

There is a general reason for concern about the impact of new media in high-profile trials, said John J. Donohue III, a Stanford Law School professor who studied the Connecticut death penalty and wrote a report that said they were arbitrarily enforced.
Professor Donohue suggested the idea that limiting instant communication from courtrooms might intrigue some judges, making trials fairer.
The Twitter issue is just one of many outlined by Mr. Hayes's lawyers that are likely to be argued for years, delaying its execution.

The defense lawyers also claim, for example, that Mr. Hayes may have been prejudiced when Judge Blue declined to allow us to test potential jurors' reactions by showing them grisly crime-scene photographs during jury selection.
Some of the jurors have said the photographs of the victims, Jennifer Hawke-Petit, 48, and her daughters, Hayley, 17, and Michaela, 11, horrified them.

The defense lawyers say that the judge wrongly removed a juror who had been critical of prosecutors and that he improperly added pressure for a verdict by his unusual decision to direct the jury to deliberate over a weekend, and they will also challenge the constitutionality of the death penalty and argue that they believe he did so.
They did not sequester the jurors.
But the arguments about the effect of the intense coverage of the trial may draw the most interest from them.
In a challenge to the verdict they filed last month, the case dominated the news in Connecticut and was discussed during the election campaign by candidates for governor and the United States Senate.
The news media argued that they continually fanned the flames of emotion about the case.
The daily crush of media tweets, cameras and reporters outside the courthouse, which the lawyers wrote, was unlike anything ever seen here in New Haven and maybe statewide.
The Twitter coverage of their focus is controversial.

In interviews, some journalists claimed that the view that instant news was more incendiary than reports delivered slowly was a Luddite perspective that would make for poor court policy in governing their coverage of future trials.
But some lawyers said arguments that social and technological changes required adaptation by the courts were often attractive to appeals courts.
That claim is being pressed by Mr. Hayes's lawyers.

In their filing, they referred to the Supreme Court's 1966 decision overturning Dr. Sheppard's conviction because of the trial coverage and made it clear we would claim that the new media required new rules.
This case, they wrote, represents the Maxwell v. Sheppard of the 21st century.

The possibility of new types of life on Earth, or elsewhere is raised by arsenic-tolerant microbes.
A strange bacteria that can use arsenic as one of their nutrients has widened the scope for finding new forms of life on Earth and possibly beyond with its discovery.
While the unusual bacteria were discovered here on Earth by researchers, they say they show that life can have possibilities beyond the major elements that have been considered essential.
It has dual capabilities.
Either phosphorus or arsenic can facilitate its growth.

That makes them very peculiar, though they fall short of being some form of truly 'alien' life, commented Paul C. W. Davies of Arizona State University, a co-author of the report appearing in Thursday's online edition of the journal Science.
Life has long been considered to depend on six major elements - carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen, phosphorus, and sulfur.
But the researchers found that the bacteria, discovered in Mono Lake, Calif., are able to continue growing after substituting phosphorus with arsenic.
You wonder what else is possible, said Ariel D. Anbar of Arizona State University, a co-author of the report.
The find is important in the search for life beyond Earth because they need to be able to recognize life, to know what it looks like, Anbar said.
A microbe found on Earth is the focus of the study.

However, the announcement of a news conference to discuss them, which did not disclose details of the find, generated widespread speculation on the Internet that the report would disclose the discovery of extraterrestrial life.
They didn't.

The discovery `` does show that in other planetary environments they might be able to use other elements to drive biochemistry and that the ` standard ' set of elements we think they are absolutely necessary for life might not be so fixed , `` commented Charles Cockell , professor at Planetary and Space Sciences Research Institute , Open University , in Milton Keynes , United Kingdom .
The research team did not include Cockell.
It was not a discovery by chance.
Felisa Wolfe-Simon of NASA's Astrobiology Institute, who led the study, targeted Mono Lake because they have high arsenic levels.
Arsenic and phosphorus are chemically similar, so a microbe speculated that she might be able to substitute one for the other when exposed to both.
Arsenic is toxic mainly because its chemical behavior is so similar to that of them.
As a result, these elements have a hard time being told apart by organisms.
The researchers collected the bacteria known as GFAJ-1 and exposed them to increasing concentrations of arsenic, which they were able to adapt to and grow in.

The microbe does grow better on phosphorus, but showing that they can live with arsenic instead raises the possibility that life forms using arsenic could occur naturally, either elsewhere on Earth or on another planet or moon where arsenic is more common.

Jamie S. Foster, an assistant professor of microbiology at the University of Florida, said the idea that arsenic could be substituted for phosphorus isn't new, but there has never been an example where they were shown to work.
Arsenic was more common in the early times on Earth, she said, so it might have been used by early life forms, researchers have speculated.
That does suggest there could be other ways to form life, not just how life formed on early Earth, said Foster, who was not part of the research team led by Wolfe-Simon.
NASA, the Department of Energy, and the National Institutes of Health supported the research.
The routine of democracy
Backing for private enterprise in Latin America continues to edge up, as does support for democracy.
Unemployment has become a smaller worry than crime.
And the United States is seen as less influential than Brazil across much of the region.
These are some of the findings of the latest Latinobarmetro poll taken in 18 countries and published exclusively by The Economist.
Because the poll has been taken regularly since 1995, they track changes in attitude across the region.
Two related things stand out in the results of that year's poll, taken in September and early October.
Latin America's fairly sunny mood is the first.
The second is the increasing stability of attitudes towards its core institutions and democracy.
Support for democracy in several countries on the Pacific rim of South America has noticeably risen (see table 1).
For example in Peru, where economic growth has averaged 6% a year since 2002, democracy has seen its support rise from a low of 40% in 2005 to 61% this year.
But only around half of the region's two most populous countries, Mexico and Brazil, are convinced democrats, which drags down the average regional score (see chart 2).

Some 44 % of respondents across the region pronounced themselves satisfied with how our country's democracy works in practice, the same figure as last year but a big increase on the 25 % in 2001 (chart 3).
Some 34 % said they had confidence in our country's Congress and 45 % in our government, the same as last year in both cases but up sharply from 2003 (17 % and 24 % respectively).
A decade ago economic woes in Latin America undermined democracy's support for them.
It is probably because many Latin American countries suffered only a brief recession and have enjoyed a strong recovery that they have held up during the world financial crisis.
In addition, the poor have been helped by a stronger social safety net.

The United Nations' Economic Commission for Latin America reported this week that the proportion of Latin Americans living in poverty fell only marginally in 2009 and has risen again this year, to 32%.
But the mood in each country varies widely from that of another (see chart 4).
The strong economic performance of Brazil and the popularity of its outgoing president, Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, reflect a widely shared sense of progress in them.
This is scarcer in Mexico and Central America, where it was more severe and violent crime has worsened.

For only the second time since the polls began, more respondents across Latin America as a whole cite unemployment, rather than crime, as the most important problem facing their country (see chart 5).
Some 31 % say that either we or a close relative have been victims of crime over the past year, but that is down from 38 % last year and is the lowest figure since 1995.

A more robust economic performance is reflected in rising support for private enterprise and the market economy: some 71% of respondents across the region say private enterprise is indispensable for their development, up from 56% in 2007 (see chart 6).
Some 58 % agree that the market economy is the only system that will make our country developed, up from 47 % last year.

Healthcare law challengers dine with Scalia and Thomas as the court takes the case

The day the Supreme Court gathered behind closed doors to consider the politically divisive question of whether they would hear a challenge to President Obama's healthcare law, two of their justices, Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas, were feted at a dinner sponsored by the law firm that will argue the case before the high court.
Last Thursday was the occasion, when all nine justices met for a conference to pour over the petitions they were reviewing.

One of the cases at issue was a suit brought against 26 states by Congress, challenging the sweeping healthcare overhaul passed last year, a law that has been a rallying cry for conservative activists nationwide.

The suit was agreed to be heard by the justices; indeed, a landmark 5.5-hour argument is expected in March, and the outcome is likely to further roil the 2012 presidential race, which will be in full swing by the time their decision is released.

Almost two dozen firms, including Bancroft PLLC, which is Clement's law firm, sponsored the annual dinner of the Federalist Society, a longstanding group they are dedicated to advocating conservative legal principles.
Jones Day, the firm that sponsored the dinner, represents they National Federation of Independent Business, one of the trade associations that challenged the law.
Another sponsor was pharmaceutical giant Pfizer Inc, which has an enormous financial stake in the outcome of that litigation.
A Washington hotel hosted the dinner hours after the court's conference over the case concluded.
Among others in attendance was Mitch McConnell, the Senate's top Republican, who is an avowed opponent of the healthcare law.
Scalia and Thomas were the featured guests at the dinner.
It's nothing new: The Federalist Society events have been attended by the two justices for years.
And it's nothing that they run afoul of ethics rules.
In fact, the Code of Conduct that governs the actions of lower federal justices does not apply to them.

If we were, we arguably fell under code's Canon 4C, which states, ``A judge may attend fund-raising events of law-related and other organizations although the judge may not be a speaker, a guest of honor, or featured on the program of such an event.``
Nevertheless, the sheer proximity of two of the law firms in the case, as well as a company with a massive financial interest, to Scalia and Thomas was enough to alarm ethics-in-government activists.

This stunning breach of ethics and indifference to the code belies the claims by several justices that all other federal judges abide by the same rules as the court, said Bob Edgar, the president of Common Cause.
The attorneys were wining and dining at a black-tie fundraiser with justices who have pending cases before the court.
Our appearance and assistance in fundraising for that event undercuts any claims of impartiality, and is unacceptable.
Scalia and Thomas have shown little regard for critics who say the business of the court is too readily mixed with agenda-driven groups, such as the Federalist Society, by them.
And Ginni, Thomas's wife, is a high-profile conservative activist.
Moreover, conservatives argue that it's Scalia and Thomas who have an ethical issue, not Justice Elena Kagan.
The first legal challenges to the law were brought against Kagan, who served as solicitor general in the Obama administration, at the trial court level.
Her critics have pushed for Kagan to recuse herself from hearing the case, saying that they believe she was too invested in defending the law then to be impartial now.
Kagan has given no indication that he will do so.

Is the economy burdened or enhanced by immigration?

Nicolas Sarkozy's immigration policy was criticised on various aspects, including a congestion of police, legal and administrative services, which were subjected to a policy of numbers and the compatibility of this policy with the country's self-proclaimed status as the champion of French human rights.

More recently, it is the administrative harassment of foreign students that is topical, with the minister of the interior ("Libration" on 23 May) declaring that they "do not need France's talent, bricklayers, and waiters."
But it is only rarely that the economic viewpoint is analyzed.
There is a lot of consensus between the Right and the Left on this subject.

On the Right, the tone was set by Jacques Chirac, who declared in 1976 that '900,000 of them would not become a problem in a country with 2 million of us foreign workers,' and on the Left by Michel Rocard explaining in 1990 that France 'cannot accommodate all of our world's misery.'
The only difference, the degree of their generosity
In 2005, the fear of invasion of their national territory by hordes of Polish plumbers was felt both by the Left and by the Right.
Both sides see immigrants as a burden on the economy and society of the French.
The only difference resides in the degree of generosity, which immigrants deign to receive from one.
In his program, Franois Hollande confines himself to banalities, saying that co-development would allow our problem with immigration to be solved by them.
This notion of immigration being a burden and a problem, may be an electoral asset, but they are economically very costly.

As we are reminded by the economists Ian Goldin and Geoffrey Cameron in a recent book summarising the most recent knowledge of immigration (Exceptional People: How Migration Shaped Our World and Will Define Our Future, mai 2011, Princeton University Press, 352 pp.), there is wide consensus among specialists on the positive impact of migration flows on economic growth, wages, and employment in countries that admit immigrants.
Anaemic growth and harmed employment result from restraining immigration.
Fears about the impact of immigrants are based on the notion that we are liable to be replaced by native workers, in particular unskilled ones, exerting downward pressure on wages.
But experience shows that in reality immigrants are much more complementary to us, rather than replacements of local labor, exercising trades in which there is a shortage of our labor.
Sectors which do not attract local labor and the most highly skilled ones in dynamic sectors where training is not linked to offers of employment do not employ unskilled immigrants.
Wages have a positive effect on them

In the same way as a surgeon would find them difficult to work in a country with a shortage of anaesthetists, the complementarities existing between locals and immigrants bring them about that the arrival of immigrants has a positive effect on the pay of locals.
A rise of 1 % in the migratory flow causes an increase of between 0,6 and 0,9 % in real long-term pay, as Giovanni Peri has calculated.

And does that without taking them into account, the fact that a large proportion of naturalised immigrants are among American Nobel prize winners, whilst Yahoo, Google, Intel, Paypal, and eBay were all founded by us.
Migrants are also net contributors to their social systems, averaging 1% of the total budgets of European countries.

The World Labor Organisation estimates that for example in Germany, an immigrant arriving at the age of 30 will make a net contribution (receipts less expenditure) of an average of 150,000 Euros to public budgets during her lifetime.
The teeth in question, intended to dissuade immigrants, had precisely the opposite effect on them.
